arm_group.arm_group_label: Usual patient education + standard educational websites
Usual patient education + P3P decision support website

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine whether using the P3P website can increase
      decisional preparation and satisfaction, and decrease decisional conflict, in men deciding
      how to manage early stage prostate cancer.

clinical_study.brief_title: Personal Patient Profile - Prostate (P3P) II: Effectiveness-Implementation Trial in Diverse Health Care Networks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Biopsy-proven diagnosis of prostate cancer, T1 or T2 of any risk level

          -  Biopsy done at enrolling site

          -  Upcoming appointment with consulting specialist at enrolling study site

          -  Able to read, write, understand English

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Two or more post-biopsy specialist consults

          -  Begun treatment (or active surveillance)

intervention.arm_group_label: Usual patient education + P3P decision support website
intervention.description: Website supporting informed patient decision making about prostate cancer care through tailored education and coaching

intervention.arm_group_label: Usual patient education + standard educational websites
intervention.description: Standard prostate cancer information websites (e.g., NCI, ASCO) presented to patients in addition to patient education that is usual in their clinics

clinical_study.official_title: Personal Patient Profile - Prostate (P3P) II: Effectiveness-Implementation Trial in Diverse Health Care Networks

primary_outcome.description: Graham and O'Connor, 1995, Preparation for decision making scale
Holmes-Rovner et al, 1996, Satisfaction with decision scale

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Odds ratio of selecting a care option for prostate cancer concordant with avoiding prioritized side effects (XBRT or brachytherapy if concerned with sexual function; prostatectomy if concerned with bowel function; active surveillance if concerned with sexual, bowel, and/or bladder function; any treatment if not concerned with any side effect).
secondary_outcome.measure: Concordance of care choice selected with self-reported influential personal preferences

secondary_outcome.description: Cost to the patient will be measured in hours valued according to patient work status, income, and use of time. Benefit will be measured with Willingness to pay.
secondary_outcome.measure: Net cost and benefit of the intervention

secondary_outcome.description: Duration (in days) from pre-decision baseline questionnaire until patient decides on a care option for prostate cancer, either an active treatment type or active surveillance. Measured by patient recall at 6-months.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label
